misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the distance between two points instead of a grade calculator that reads one numeric grade (0–100) and prints the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: I believe that for this question I should write a program that reads coordinates of two points (x1, y1, x2, y2) and computes the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, then use conditional logic to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program class and logic refer to distance between points rather than grades.
Inputs are x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value.
There are no conditionals checking grade ranges or printing any letter grade.
Output text is 'The distance of the two points is ...' instead of 'Letter grade: ...'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment problems or not carefully reading the specific requirements for Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and identify the required input (one grade), the processing (range checks using if/else), and the required output (a letter grade). Before coding, write down these three pieces to ensure your program structure matches the task.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is structured around distance calculation with no mention of grades or letter outputs, which clearly does not match the grade calculator specification.

evidence.note: All variables, prompts, and computations relate to points and distance; there is no reading of a single grade or any letter-grade logic.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Goal
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program designed to calculate the distance between two points, not the required Grade Calculator program. None of the project requirements (reading a grade, conditional grading logic, outputting a letter grade) were met.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task for Q3 required writing a program to compute the distance between two coordinate points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic (if/else if/else) to output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Program prompts for four separate coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2)
The logic implements the distance formula (square root of the sum of squared differences)
The program output is the distance between the points, not a letter grade
No conditional (if/else) logic for grading is present
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have submitted code for a different assignment or failed to read the prompt entirely and substituted a recognized geometry problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt for Q3 carefully. The submitted code must implement the logic for the Grade Calculator problem described in the question.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code structure, variable names (x1, y1, x2, y2), and calculation (Math.sqrt) unambiguously show the distance formula, which is completely irrelevant to the Grade Calculator problem.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a complete and correct program for computing the distance between two points, but this does not address the problem, which asks for a grade-to-letter-grade converter using numeric ranges and conditionals. The program never reads a single numeric grade, never checks any of the specified ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.), and never outputs a letter grade. As a result, none of the rubric categories (reading numeric grade input, Boolean ranges for A/B and C/D, handling F, mapping ranges to letters) are satisfied, and this would score 0/5 for the question.
misconceptions.student_belief: I believe the task is to read coordinates for two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2), compute the Euclidean distance using the distance formula, and print that numeric distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, use an if/else-if/else chain (or equivalent conditionals) to check which numeric range it falls into (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, C: 70–79, D: 60–69, F: below 60), and then print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1 and y1, then x2 and y2, instead of a single numeric grade.
Variables represent coordinates and deltas (x1, y1, x2, y2, delta_x, delta_y) rather than a grade value.
The code computes a square root of a sum of squares rather than checking numeric ranges with conditionals.
Output is a distance value, not a letter grade such as A, B, C, D, or F.
There are no if/else or switch statements to implement the required range-based logic.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have confused this problem with a different assignment (distance between two points) or reused a template from another exercise without adapting it to the given specification. This reflects a misunderstanding of how to translate specific problem requirements (inputs, processing logic, and required outputs) into code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and identify: (1) the required input (a single numeric grade 0–100), (2) the processing (an if/else-if/else chain that checks which numeric interval the grade belongs to), and (3) the required output (the corresponding letter A, B, C, D, or F). Rewrite main so it uses one grade variable, reads it with Scanner, then uses conditionals to map it to the correct letter and prints that letter.
related_concepts: Using if-else chains for range checking
Designing program input and output based on specifications
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program is focused on distance-between-points computation, and there is no trace of grade-related variables, ranges, or letter-grade output.

evidence.note: Shows the program is reading four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade.
The core computation and output are for a distance value, not for determining or printing a letter grade.

misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely unrelated to the 'Grade Calculator' problem described in Q3. It is a completely different program (Distance between points).

misconceptions.name: Complete Problem Misunderstanding
